is larger than the size of the input, the input is padded by appending zeros at the end. Even though this is the common approach, it might lead to surprising results. If a different padding is desired, it must be performed before calling
y[k] = np.sum(x * np.exp(2j * np.pi * k * np.arange(n)/n)) / len(x)
has support for all floating point types and is optimized for real input.
Length of the transformed axis of the output. If
is smaller than the length of the input, the input is cropped. If it is larger, the input is padded with zeros. If
is not given, the length of the input along the axis specified by
is used. See notes about padding issues.
Axis over which to compute the inverse DFT. If not given, the last axis is used.
